TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Ambassador PERSON , Head of ORG at ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant is the chairperson of ORG ( ORG gegen DATE “ the Association ” ) , an association for the protection of animals .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , as chairperson of the ORG , notified , in accordance with LAW , ORG ) that the ORG intended to hold an assembly , namely to set up a public information booth in the pedestrian zone in GPE on DATE between TIME and TIME and on DATE between TIME and TIME in order to inform people of the suffering of fur - bearing animals . He indicated that he expected that CARDINAL people would man the booth and added that the following material would be used : a display of posters , banners , leaflets , tables , an electricity generator , a petition on which signatures would be gathered , a video projector , a projection screen and a car ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , PERSON , ORG , GPE , ORG ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG set up its information booth in the city of GPE . It set up a table with a television screen and a video projector fed by an electric generator and showed a documentary on the suffering of fur - bearing animals used for scientific experiments and for the production of fur , while CARDINAL or CARDINAL people belonging to the ORG distributed leaflets . Several people held banners and chanted slogans . Passers - by were able to sign a petition in support of the ORG ’s stance and some of them entered into discussions with the animal rights activists .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , on DATE , ORG issued a penal order against the applicant in the amount of CARDINAL ( ORG ) , finding that the ORG had not requested prior authorisation by the competent authority under section CARDINAL of ORG – hereinafter “ the GPE ” ) . As no such permit had been obtained from ORG , the applicant as the person responsible for the ORG had committed an administrative offence .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Unabhängiger Verwaltungssenat ) dismissed an appeal lodged by the applicant , holding that pursuant to section CARDINAL of the Roads Act the use of streets for any other purpose than their prescribed and intended one required permission , irrespective of whether setting up the information booth had itself been permitted under LAW . It further held that setting up the information booth could not be considered as an “ assembly ” within the ordinary meaning of LAW , as its main purpose had been to inform people rather than getting people together for a common purpose .

CARDINAL . Thereupon the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG on DATE , complaining of a violation of the right to peaceful assembly under LAW . In his opinion , section CARDINAL of LAW did not apply to setting up an information booth .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s complaint . ORG found that setting up the information booth qualified as an event protected by LAW Staatsgrundgesetz ) concerning freedom of assembly and association . The right to peaceful assembly was guaranteed by LAW and specified by LAW ) and any breach of that Act therefore constituted a violation of the underlying fundamental right . It found that the act of setting up the information booth in question fell within the scope of LAW .

CARDINAL . The Assembly Act provided that an assembly only had to be notified to the authorities and did not require prior authorisation . Therefore , any system requiring prior authorisation of an assembly was in principle inconsistent with the right to peaceful assembly and unconstitutional . The question was therefore whether the requirements of section QUANTITY of LAW , which required permission for the special use of a road , were in accordance with these provisions of constitutional law . In ORG view , ORG had been bound to interpret LOC in conformity with LAW ( verfassungskonforme Interpretation ) and had therefore been obliged to issue the relevant permission . This meant that section DATE of LAW was constitutional .

CARDINAL . As regards whether fining the applicant for having failed to ask for a permit under section CARDINAL of LAW had violated the applicant ’s rights under LAW , the Constitutional Court found that there had been no such breach given that section CARDINAL of LAW was in conformity with LAW ; ORG had been obliged by constitutional law to deliver the relevant permission ; and the fine imposed on the applicant had been moderate .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Roads Act reads , insofar as relevant , as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Any use of the road ... for any other purpose than it was intended for requires the explicit permission of ORG . ... ”
CARDINAL . Section QUANTITY of the Roads Act reads , insofar as relevant , as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) A breach of section ... DATE ... is an administrative offence liable to be punished by the ORG with a fine of up to ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL or with imprisonment in default [ of payment ] of DATE . Fines levied shall be passed on to ORG and used for road maintenance purposes . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Assembly Act reads as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) PERSON wants to hold a public assembly where access is not restricted to invited guests only shall notify the [ relevant ] authority in writing at least TIME before the intended event specifying its purpose , the place and the time of the assembly . The notification must reach the authority at latest TIME before the time of the assembly .
( CARDINAL ) Upon request the authority must immediately issue a certificate [ attesting to ] the notification of the assembly . ORG is not subject to any fee . ”
